content.body: is there generally accepted JS jargon for what I've been calling "user code calls"? that is, when some innocuous-looking JS code that doesn't obviously call a function, does actually call a function that may be defined somewhere else in the code (like `+value` may end up calling `value[Symbol.toPrimitive]()`, etc.)
content.formatted_body: is there generally accepted JS jargon for what I've been calling "user code calls"? that is, when some innocuous-looking JS code that doesn't obviously call a function, does actually call a function that may be defined somewhere else in the code (like +value may end up calling value[Symbol.toPrimitive](), etc.)

content.body: I don't know. I call it "trigger user code"
yeah i think it's that or "can call user code" is what the spec's u mode does
* yeah i think it's that or "can call user code" is what the spec's u mode says

m.new_content.body: yeah i think it's that or "can call user code" is what the spec's u mode says

content.body: I think it's confusing who the "user" actually is
when we work as a framework/spec/library/engine developer, the user actually means other developer but using this term is strange I agree
"user code" is code not under your control, so it's relative
i don't think it's confusing in practice, since the frame of reference is usually pretty clear, whether it's a spec or a framework
